Articles.Content: Squad mentioned earlier they reworked things so they could know the exact time at which a ship changed SoI, so that warping across a boundary at high speed no longer resulted in your orbit predictions being way off. Being able to do the same for water impacts was probably a nice secondary result of this change.

> 
> Has anybody noticed this bit: "from proper detection and placement of splashdown effects at very high speeds (now that thatÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s possible)"? Maybe they've reworked the water?

I took that to mean that higher impact speeds are now possible because the atmosphere is no longer soupy.

I'll add my name to the list of people that don't want to see the Round 8 changed. Given it's ring shape is extremely useful as it is. 

If Squad want's a 1.25m xenon tank then why not just build a new one? Or better yet, make all tanks toggleable like B9 Aerospace.

> 
> Looking at the ROUND8's stats, it was redundant with the Oscar-Tank, except in terms of design. We needed an inline Xenon tank much more than we needed another low-capacity LFO tank for probes. 
> You are, of course, free to mod it back to its original specs if you want to, or create another cfg to have both variants. ![:)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_smiley.gif)
> 
> Cheers

Or you could have simply cloned the part giving it xenon and a silver foil texture and left a frequently used part intact. I can't for the life of me fathom why you or your team felt the round8 had to go.

Just a couple of thoughts some of you might not have considered:

- The capacity of the Oscar-B might have been changed to be identical to the Round-8, which would explain HarvesteR's response
- Some of you are complaining that new features are being added instead of just final tweaks, but have you considered that all of the new parts/features mentioned in the OP could be in response to experimentals feedback? None of these features are major game changers and can be considered final tweaks (even the new parts)

Having said that, I'm sad to see the Toroidal tank changed to ion. As many have pointed out, we *do* need a larger ion tank, but that tank is a one of a kind from a design perspective. The Oscar doesn't replace it, even if the Oscar has been edited to the same capacity.

More parts!? I'm kinda flipping out! I was afraid I'd have to work with dozens of mods to get the variation I needed! Maybe I can play entirely stock now that there's a stock heating and aerodynamics system!

Don't get me wrong, I love the system currently in the game. But once you try the game with mods, it's hard not to mod later.![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

I'd like to chime in with the others here: The Round-8 is far more useful as an LF&O tank than a xenon tank.

 An ion-powered probe has no need to worry about staging and physical compactness, and this is what the toroidal tank is best at.

 While we'd all love a larger xenon tank, there's no benefit to having it be toroidal.

 So \*please\*... if you want to re-task something as a xenon tank, please don't use the Round-8.

Best,

-Slashy

> 
> An ion-powered probe has no need to worry about staging and physical compactness

Bigger tanks open possibilities for ions other than probes. Ions make great orbital propulsion, but the part count gets out of hand quickly with the current tiny tanks. Plus staging fewer than four of them is inefficient due to the relative masses of decouplers and dry xenon tanks. Bigger tanks make larger ion craft much more palatable.

> 
> I thought it was the terrible TWR that was - from a gameplay perspective - still way too low even though it beat real ion engines by factors of ... hundreds was it? I don't actually know because just thinking about using them gives me shivers.

The PB-ION is based on the NEXT, most likely, which is 236 **MILLI**newtons of thrust. The PB-ION is 2 **KILO**newtons of thrust.. or 8,474.6 times more powerful. You could even say that's "roughly ten thousand times more powerful".

A real ion engine is basically useless for anything other than probes that don't give a damn that their burn times measured in months and years (ex the Dawn spacecraft's total burn time is about 5.5 *years*) - the 90 to 230 millinewtons of thrust is roughly equivalent to lifting 0.5 to 2 sheets of paper in Earth's gravity (based on my postage scale's reading on the weight of a couple of papers anyhow, they might be on the heavy side compared to some as they're laser papers with print on 'em).

The ion strength in KSP is one of the #lolfake factors. It's worse than the reaction wheels, and possibly even the jet engines. That being said, an actual real-world ion drive would be totally useless in KSP, as the net acceleration that craft experience due to physics (the k-drive effect, which is present in almost any vehicle that's more than one part) would utterly dominate the craft's acceleration. That, and nobody sane would want to sit through a 5 year burn at 4x phys warp~ So Squad decided to #lol it up and make it so it's useful. Er.. useful-ish.

Also, this completely ignores the #lolsolar problem that the stock curves are extra-fake and unauthentic, but also that #lolstats have zero mass~ With proper light falloff calculations (which, miraculously enough, don't give a damn about scale - if Kerbin is receiving 1.0x light, Duna is receiving about 0.42x light, in stock, 3.2x, 6.4x, or full RSS sizes), most of the outer system would be largely inaccessible to solar craft as the light levels would be much weaker.

The thing about KSP is that you can keep on adding stuff, there's so much *potential* for depth in this game. Maybe even GP2! More parts! A freaking KSP *sequel*!
> Excuse me while I engage the hype engines!

I believe (and if I'm correct, agree with) his point was that a projected finish line *is a good thing*. Maybe we want to someday learn that, while new *small* features might continually and slowly still be added *where needed*, we don't have to start over our savegames again because, say, someone decided to finally do away with a placeholder crappy aerodynamics some rely on. Or remove a part some people use. Or suddenly make reentry death a thing. Or break their own code in unexpected ways by changing a major physics system, instead of, say, adding a new character or skill. You said so yourself: "After that, who knows?"

I don't want development to halt after 1.0, but I did wish it was the version where it could be said "the game is finished, but will still be polished", rather than "it's good enough to sell as good enough, but me might eventually pull the rug on you again. And again."

- - - Updated - - -

That said, I do agree that GP2 and more parts would be good post-1.0 additions. Even a sequel would be appreciated, provided it was significantly different and/or better that a new version. There IS so much potential for depth in this game.

I don't agree that the Round8 was redundant with the Oscar-b. With that logic you might as well remove all FL-T\* tanks except the FL-T100, since they're all multiples of it. As well as all Rockomax tanks except the X8. (forgot the exact name, 800 units of LFO)

My small probes with an ant engine get at least a Round8 and an Oscar-b to get a decent amount of delta-v. A small probe with a single Oscar-b is on the low side in delta-v, but an FL-T100 is overkill and looks bad. There definitely needs to be more than one tank option for the 0.675m parts. If you're going to repurpose the Round8 for Xenon because its looks aren't consistent with other LFO tanks, new LFO tanks for the 0.675m diameter are needed.

From a gameplay perspective, if ion drives are to power larger craft than probes, please also consider a larger version of the ion engine along with the needed power generation options to prevent the need to cluster the small ones excessively.
